subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy

messageBody:
Adam Jack wrote:

> You guys all seem very caught up on decoupling, and I'll
> acknowledge I am far from an OO purist, I have a job to do &
> I write code.

I do have a job to do / write code, too. To the extent I am an "OO
purist", I am one because it helps me write better code faster. As does
Junit - among other things by bringing coupling problems to light.

> I attempt to write standalone (decoupled)
> classes, I attempt to make them have well structed "APIs" but
> at the end of the day, if A uses B (however implemented, and
> however used -- aggregation, subclassing, command/messaging paradigms,
> whatever) *for whatever reason* then surely for A to work, B
> ought work?

No. A can use B without even knowing about it! And if it doesn't know
about B, you can simply replace B with B' for your A-tests.

> I don't think we ever gave these fair hearing because (I
> feel) we spent all the time on why the idea was bad. To be
> frank, I didn't think anybody was listening,

I think the more constructive approach might be to question ones own
ability to explain instead of the others willingness to listen. I might
be wrong.

> I think the points (one by one) that need to get agreed or dismissed
> are:
>
> 1) Are test suites (as collections of tests, which have some
> hierarchical/run order effect) are a "second place" to manage
> relationship between testcases? Since managing in two places
> is always flawed, are suites flawed? [If I refactor testcases
> I might forget to refactor the suites, and that is where errors creep
> in.]

Please explain wether you are speaking about manually or automatically
constructed suites here (or both?).

> 2) Are test suites becoming obsoleted by "brute force
> collectors"? How would we know other than a user survey?

It seems to me that the TestSuite class can't become obsolete by
collectors, as the collectors need to use it. So I don't understand what
you'd like to do based on that survey.

> 3) If "suites" have outlived their purpose, why are they the
> "framework" way to manage run order?

They aren't. They are the frameworks way to have a hierarchical
collection of tests. I don't know of any alternative.

> 4) Does "run order/dependency" (not side-effect dependency)
> have any value -- despite it's smell?

Of course it does, to some users of the framework. And there are already
tools out there providing that value. If they don't suffice, it would be
very easy to implement your own.

> 5) Is "run order" something that ought be in the framework, however
> it is implemented.

"Run order" is something that is in the framework. How to decide about
run order isn't - and shouldn't be, IMHO.

> As agree w/ David, in a mail I sent yesterday but haven't
> seen list exploded yet, I *may* be right about some of this,
> but I don't think dependency will get an open hearing 'cos of
> the stench of side-effect dependency. So be it.

If you think so, perhaps we should stop this discussion?


Regards, Ilja
